Posts.Content: Oct 20, 2013 07:58PM redroks2 wrote: Abbott...I've been at this for almost three months and I STILL don't have answers so yes...patience is a virtue! And if virtue were a baseball bat I would be spreading my virtue all over the place! :) Yeah for the Breast Cancer program! For future reference though, often times if they know you have to pay out of pocket, you will receive a reduced rate. Also, you can ask them for a payment plan. By law, there can not be interest charged on medical procedures so you wouldn't be paying anything extra if you chose a payment plan. Your deductible really isn't too terribly high but the I know, the 80/20 can kill ya. We switched to an HMO about 10 years ago and although there's pluses and minuses to everything, I know without a doubt that we would be living in a box under a bridge if we had a PPO. Around here, we get the mammo and u/s results right there in the room so there is no waiting to find out what they saw. Of course I always pick up my report and my CD copy on the way out! An inverted nipple IS something that warrants concern and yes, more than the lump believe it or not. On the up side, you learn a lot while you're waiting! I've done so much freakin' research that I have dreams about evil mammogram machines with sharp teeth and red eyes that gobble up boobies! :-o

Posts.Title: Worried it's IBC...any advice would help :( EmmorsMom redroks2

Posts.Content: Aug 20, 2013 10:54PM redroks2 wrote: This summer, my youngest fell off his bike (while standing still...don't ask) and bit down on his cheek pretty bad. A couple of days later I noticed a huge lump on the back of his head. The lymphnodes on the back of the skull are connected to (and "filter") around the face. Him biting his cheek caused that node to swell up and it stayed swollen for almost a month. Your poor ta-ta has been through a lot and all that infection is still working it's way out. You could still have a clogged duct but the swelling could take quite awhile to go down. All the that tissue in there is still healing. Is it still tender to the touch?
Posts.Title: Worried it's IBC...any advice would help :( EmmorsMom redroks2

Posts.Content: Aug 18, 2013 01:37AM redroks2 wrote: Definitely sounds like a bad case of Mastitis...been there, done that, SO not fun. I completely understand your worry and you're doing the right thing getting it checked out. They may just need to get you a stronger antibiotic or get it in you faster. I had to take my first dose via IV as a jumpstart. Good luck!
Posts.Title: Worried it's IBC...any advice would help :( EmmorsMom redroks2

Posts.Content: Aug 18, 2013 05:39PM redroks2 wrote: I do that all the time too. I hate taking up appointment time and then feeling like I probably shouldn't have. It's GREAT that the fever and redness is gone though! That's a good sign but I would definitely still get it looked at. Mastitis can be often be an ongoing problem and require multiple rounds of antibiotics. Worst case scenario, it can actually turn into an abcess so better to have it looked at now!

Posts.Content: Nov 2, 2013 02:15AM redroks2 wrote: The holiday's always seem to get in the way! When I was pregnant with my youngest, I had a blood test right before Christmas that came back very bad so it was fully expected that I was going to have a miscarriage for Christmas. WORST. HOLIDAY. EVER. Of course the doctor's office was closed for 4 days because the holiday fell on a Tuesday so I was depressed and on edge the whole time, it was miserable. By the time they retested my blood the following week suddenly everything had righted itself and the baby was fine. Granted he is a healthy and obnoxious six year old now but, that crappy Christmas is forever burned into my memory. No one wants to deal with this kind of stress anytime of year let alone the holiday's, so I totally understand pushing for those results before Thanksgiving! The likelihood of squeezing anything else in before the end of the year might be slim though :( And yes, new surgeon for me on Monday! I'm done playing the "wait and see" game. It's been over three months people! I've waited! And I see the same schtuff so let's get this show on the road!

Posts.Title: Trying not to worry, but..... trying2Bpatient trying2Bpatient

Posts.Content: Apr 12, 2014 03:48AM redroks2 wrote: I've had 3 negative biopsies but I continue to have problems in and around my right breast. I'm not saying the biopsies are wrong, but I have very dense breast tissue so mammo doesn't show much and the ultrasound tech always just seems to check the spots we already know about. I found the first mass almost 4 years ago and my ObGyn sent me for an ultrasound. The tech looked at it for about 5 seconds, said  she didn't see anything, and then sent me on my way. I now have a 4th mass that has shown up and the tech did the SAME thing again last week. Um, it's the size of a grape at minimum so I'm pretty sure it's not a figment of my imagination! I My point is that you have to do what is best for YOUR breasts. These puppies are not created equal so what may work for me, may not work for you. Just be aware of your options and understand the difference in their diagnostic usage. I am definitely one of those people who stays calmer with information so yes, I have done mass quantities of research BUT, you have to take the good with the bad and as a generalization only. I know what the best and worst case scenario, and all the possibilities in between, but I am my first and best advocate and I can't do that job effectively without fully understanding it all myself. All my doctors have been great but how would I know if they weren't if I didn't seek out additional information? My oldest son was born with a congenital defect and his first surgeon was fabulous, we loved her...and she screwed up huge. She failed to give us extremely pertinent information that could have cost my son his life. Ever since then, I will ALWAYS research and I will ALWAYS be sure I understand all the possibilities and that means researching the benign options as well as the not-so-benign one's. And yes, waiting SUCKS!!! Keeping busy is the best way to deal with it though so I'm thankful spring sports have started up again because it keeps me runnin'...while I'm waitin'!
Posts.Title: Wishing I had more answers... NSwrites juliaanna

Posts.Content: Oct 25, 2013 12:06PM redroks2 wrote: TotallyB, I have a super power. I was born with it, like Superman, and have wielded it to do much good! Just call me, Captain Perspective! dah-dAH-DAH! Ah, grasshopper, I see Sarahjane has gifts as well! The way this works is that whenever anyone is feeling bad about their day, or their current state of affairs, I am able to "one up" virtually everything in turn, making the other person's struggle seem far more manageable in comparison. I am impressed with SarahJane as she has outdone me! I know, I know, it seems like a strange super power to have but I use my powers for good (most of the time) and it has certainly never failed me! Waiting SUCKS. Regardless of the length of the wait, it SUCKS. SarahJane has "one upped" me, which rarely happens! :) But, I am 3 months deep into this process with NO definitive answers. Clearly SarahJane reached a whole new level of consciousness at 6 months! Yowzer! I've racked up, one mammogram, one ultrasound, one failed biopsy (oops! we missed it!), another ultrasound, another ultrasound, blood work, MRI, another ultrasound next week, followed by another biopsy. They KNOW there is something there and it doesn't look good but damitall if they can figure out what it is! All the while I have sharp pains in my ribs and a neck full of swollen lymph nodes. Is Monday sounding better yet? :) I will gladly trade! LOL Hang tight TotallyB. Find something to do this weekend, get out of the house, rent a movie, whatever you can to keep your mind occupied and Monday will come a little quicker and with a little less stress. You're more than welcome to borrow my six year old, he has a super power too! His epic whining will melt your brain and then you won't have to think about it all! Just an option...throwing it out there. All appendages crossed that Monday brings you a bouquet of benign! *hugs*

Posts.Content: Oct 25, 2013 12:26PM redroks2 wrote: Ooooh, the force is strong in here! Cactus, *bow*, I see you are a chartered member of WFS (waiting friggin' sucks). I am also a "more information = calm" type person and I FULLY agree that little personality trait makes the wait down right maddening. Several years ago I had to wait 3 months on a test that was literally going to tell me whether or not my 8 year old was going to live or die. I called the doctors office right at 90 days to find out they had gotten the results back in 30 days and no one called me. Granted, the test was negative but could you imagine if it hadn't been!? I'd be in jail right now...no joke. I'm pretty sure the nurse was crying by the time I hung up the phone. Not my proudest moment...but it's B.S. that the life and death stuff takes longer!

Posts.Content: Sep 17, 2013 08:53PM redroks2 wrote: YIKES - Miscarriage is one of those situations where people almost always end up with diarrhea of the mouth because they have no clue what to say. After three, I really realized that a lot of people don't really consider it a loss. I understand that to a point. Unless you have kids or have been through a miscarriage yourself, it can be hard to understand and some people really don't think of it as a "baby" regardless of how far along you are. As I was walking out of the ER my sister in law said, "things happen for a reason". I had just lost a few pints of blood and wasn't really in the mood to be cordial so I looked her straight in the eye and said, "you mean my baby was meant to die? why would it be meant to die?" She has never spoken a word about my miscarriages again! *note, she has no kids. And Momof4, said sister in law is the same one who also will go on, and on, and on about whatever lame ass medical condition she is dealing with (usually migraines) but then totally skips over asking how her nephew and godchild is doing after SURGERY. Sadly, you can't fix stupid and you can't beat out narcissism...though I wish we could!

Posts.Content: Aug 18, 2013 06:30AM redroks2 wrote: A dominant lump in the breast is any lump that is new, larger, harder, or different in any other way from the rest of the breast tissue and can certianly be as harmless as a cyst or a fibroadenoma  A palpable breast mass is defined as a dominant mass if it is 3-dimensional, distinct from surrounding tissues, and asymmetrical relative to the other breast. A dominant mass will persist throughout a menstrual cycle (certainly not the case for you ). Smooth, welldemarcated dominant masses that are mobile are often benign.  A "nodule" is simply a term used by the radiologist to describe anomalies. Nodule/mass/lump/growth...it's semantics.  #fingerscrossedforyou

Posts.Content: Sep 2, 2013 09:51PM redroks2 wrote: I'm going to be 36 in ten days, 2 boys (10 & 6). I spent a week deciding if I should call the doctor, a week waiting for the appointment, a week of testing, and then another week of waiting for results...and I too know nothing other than, "You have a mass of unknown etiology". Awesome (insert eye roll here). Since the intense squish of the mammogram resulted in an abscess (barf!) everything that needs to be done has been pushed back FOUR LONG AGONIZING WEEKS to allow for antibiotics and tissue recovery. Blah, blah, blah *pouting* For the most part I am doing okay but of course, I have my moments that catch me off guard and I have to take a deep breath down to my toes. Other times we make totally tasteless jokes  I keep telling my husband, it's not a tumor. My brain got so large a piece fell off and landed in my ta-ta and now, not only does it have a "mind of it's own" but it KNOWS things, like when you're lying about how much you really paid for that new Coleman Cooler. I also pulled the tumor card to get the last cupcake. I'm not proud of it but, I really wanted the cupcake  My kids knew I had a small procedure when the abscess (barf!) was drained but, my ten year old is certainly more perceptive. He hasn't asked me anything specific but, I can tell he knows something is up. His birthday is just seven days away so, despite my lack of patience, I'm glad any potential bad news will come after. I've only told a couple of family members and a few bestest good friends. Your family are there to support you and your friends are there to keep you sane...and bring liquor when required.  I have 16 more days to wait for round two of testing...meanwhile, I am drawing up eviction papers for Lumpy Lumperson!

Posts.Content: Sep 3, 2013 02:40PM redroks2 wrote: I can't comment on surgery (though my time is coming) but I will say, I am so sorry your kids know what Cancer is. Mine do not, though they are quite familiar with Alzheimer's. During a coversation about Grandma's memory a few weeks back, I did ask my oldest if he knew what cancer was and he said no. You'd think I would have been relieved but to my shock, I had quite the opposite reaction. Once I processed it for a moment I realized that explaining cancer would be more difficult for me than having to tell him I had it (if I did). He knows there are many kinds and that some are bad and some are not so bad but, nothing beyond that. I can handle just about anything with a calm face but when it comes to the kids...I'm generally a snotty, slobbering mess.  How soon is surgery? I don't know how accurate I am but from all my experiences, back surgery is by far one of the hardest recoveries so this should be gravy in comparison!  Besides, a night with a medical staff is always better than a night without one!
Posts.Title: Need some company while I wait Azwordmom redroks2

Posts.Content: Sep 10, 2013 02:22PM redroks2 wrote: It really does have a lot to do with your doctor. When I found a suspicous lump a few years ago (age 33) my ObG didn't hesitate to send me for my first Mammogram. Thank GOD she did because that became my baseline for what I'm dealing with now and that baseline has proven to be an extremely relevant reference. I think ALL women should have a baseline in their 20's and again in their 30's.  On my first visit, my surgeon asked me about family history. Well, BOTH sides are LOADED with cancer of varying forms. He asked specifically about breast cancer and I told him my Paternal Grandmother died in her 30's of breast cancer with spinal mets. He proceeded to tell me that genetically speaking, it really only "counted" if it is a first generation connection like a mother or a sister. THIS IS WHERE I CALL FOUL. I got a little snippy with him when I explained, my PATERNAL Grandma had 4 boys, 3 of whom have had cancer of a major organ (father included), I am an only child AND the only grandchild...sooooo, what were you saying about "first generation"?? When it comes to disease and the human body there should never be any kind of cookie cutter approach. Guidelines, reccomendations, sure. But no two people have the same experience, the same symptoms, or the same responses to treatment. Doctor's need to stop being afraid to think outside the box. And let's be realistic here...Cancer is cancer is cancer and when they find a cure for one, I am quite sure the rest will follow so, for me, I don't want to "Race for a Cure" because it seems...impractical. What we need right now is to "race" for early screening, mandatory baselines, screening facilities in rural areas, better facilities for low-income women, insurance coverage for genetic screening for high risk women...but, I'm just spitballin'
